newsitem.title: USA: INSIGHT - Overbought signals tease bullish T-bonds.
newsitem.headline: INSIGHT - Overbought signals tease bullish T-bonds.

text.p: U.S. Treasury bond futures' relentless bull run has again caught the market guessing whether its extended oscillator indicators are signs of strong momentum or oversold conditions, technical analysts said.

While virtually all technical and fundamental readings point to higher bond prices in the long run, concern that a correction is overdue continues to intimidate the bulls as it has throughout the market's three-month rally, they said.
Stewart Taylor, president of Taylor Consulting, said the percent-K and D values of the daily stochastic have gone above the 80 level for the third time during the rally.
Still, the uptrend has been so strong that it was dangerous to try to pick a top, he noted.
September T-bond futures extended gains today and briefly rose to a high of 115-22/32 today, taking out the December 3 high of 115-17/32, before pulling back slightly.
"You can't jump in front of a freight train just to see if it stops," Taylor said.
Terence Gabriel, a technical analyst at I.D.E.A., agreed and offered a two-sided game plan.
That target was the December 3 high on the continuation contract chart, coinciding with the low in cash bond yield, and also another significant Gann Line, he said.
Gabriel said he would become less bullish if the September contract slid below 114-1/2, but the market looked overwhelmingly bullish.

Analysts said the Commodity Research Burueau index .CRB, whose decline had helped the bonds rally in recent months, appeared to have been forming a near-term bottoming pattern in the last two weeks or so.

"We are seeing rising daily oscillators throughout this slightly upwardly sloped basing pattern," Gabriel said. "It does suggest there's a kind of internal momentum brewing for some kind of a continued gain."
But he added that the CRB index was still probably in a downtrend, merely correcting after eight straight weeks of lower weekly lows and black weekly candlesticks.
